X-E Hybrid Scheme Analysis

With most PQC schemes, their implementation is bound to affect the overall performance of the system. With their larger key and signature sizes along with slower key generation time and verification time, it is important to understand and experiment with how they work in different scenarios.

Proposition X.2.

Dilithium and XMSS are quantum T-secure. Thus, the proposed hybrid signature is also quantum secure.

The proposed hybrid scheme has a triple

(K​e​y​G​e​n​(D,X),S​i​g​n​(X),V​(V​(X,D)​V​(X)))𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝐷𝑋𝑆𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑋𝑉𝑉𝑋𝐷𝑉𝑋\left(KeyGen(D,X),Sign(X),V(V(X,D)V(X)))\right.

K​e​y​G​e​n​(D,X)𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝐷𝑋KeyGen(D,X) refers to key generation by Dilithium and XMSS, s​i​g​n​(X)𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑋sign(X) refers to signing transactions using XMSS, and verification involves verification of XMSS signatures of transactions and verification of the dilithium signature of the XMSS public key. V​(X,D)𝑉𝑋𝐷V(X,D) refers to the verification of the Dilithium signature of the XMSS public key, and V​(X)𝑉𝑋V(X) refers to the verification of the XMSS signatures. So, we can write

∀(d​K​e​y​s,x​K​e​y​s)←K​e​y​G​e​n​(1​λx,λd)←for-all𝑑𝐾𝑒𝑦𝑠𝑥𝐾𝑒𝑦𝑠𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛1subscript𝜆𝑥subscript𝜆𝑑\forall(dKeys,xKeys)\leftarrow KeyGen(1{\lambda_{x},\lambda_{d}})
∀(m∈M):V​(Vd​(d​P​k,Xp​k,dδ),Vx​(t​x,Xp​k,xδ))=1:for-all𝑚𝑀𝑉subscript𝑉𝑑𝑑𝑃𝑘subscript𝑋𝑝𝑘subscript𝑑𝛿subscript𝑉𝑥𝑡𝑥subscript𝑋𝑝𝑘subscript𝑥𝛿1\forall(m\in M):V(V_{d}(dPk,X_{p}k,d_{\delta}),V_{x}(tx,X_{pk},x_{\delta}))=1

where λd,λxsubscript𝜆𝑑subscript𝜆𝑥\lambda_{d},\lambda_{x} are security parameters for Dilithium and XMSS, respectively.

X-F Convergence Analysis

Theoretical Analysis of convergence behavior of the role selection mechanism algorithm. Assumption:[Gradient Approximation Error] In each round of communication r𝑟r, the role selection algorithm selects the set of Sdsubscript𝑆𝑑S_{d} online devices in a way such that the aggregated gradients of workers are a good approximation with error ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon.

Proposition X.3.

Consensus Convergence Time in BFL with the Proposed Miner Selection.

Proof.

In proof of work, we calculate a hash value of the block with a random nonce value that is less than a threshold value pre-defined.

Hash(nonce||Hash(block))<thresholdHash(nonce||Hash(block))<threshold

which takes around 10 minutes for Bitcoin. This time is dependent on the difficulty level, which refers to the number of zeros at the front of the hash value. Let the difficulty value be d𝑑d which is associated with several values such that

d∝n​u​m​b​e​r​O​f​Z​e​r​o​sproportional-to𝑑𝑛𝑢𝑚𝑏𝑒𝑟𝑂𝑓𝑍𝑒𝑟𝑜𝑠d\propto numberOfZeros

In the stake proof, time is not dependent on computational power.

In BFL with proposed role selection, PoS consensus is followed by final block selection of different miners comparing two VRF outputs. Therefore, consensus convergence occurs in the time it takes to compute the central VRF output and the comparison between the initial distributed VRF output value of each device i.e.,

Tc∼T​i​m​e​(Tv​c+Tc​v​r​f)similar-tosubscript𝑇𝑐𝑇𝑖𝑚𝑒subscript𝑇𝑣𝑐subscript𝑇𝑐𝑣𝑟𝑓T_{c}\sim Time(T_{vc}+T_{cvrf})

where, Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} is the time for consensus convergence, Tv​csubscript𝑇𝑣𝑐T_{vc} is the comparison of the VRF output and Tc​v​r​fsubscript𝑇𝑐𝑣𝑟𝑓T_{cvrf} is the time taken to compute the VRF output for central VRF. To put things in perspective, Tcsubscript𝑇𝑐T_{c} for Bitcoin is around 10 min, while Ethereum takes only 14 seconds. ∎

Proposition X.4.

VRF added a verification requirement unbreakable by Quantum Attacks.

Proof.

WOTS+ signing and verification introduced to ECVRF add quantum security. As shown in Definition VI-C1, for verification step 2, WOTS+ verification is required. Even if ecVRF in itself is broken by Quantum Attacks, the WOTS+ signature cannot be forged. Also, in each round i𝑖i,

s​ki,p​ki←w​o​t​s​K​e​y​G​e​n​(r​a​n​d​o​m​S​e​e​d)←𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖𝑤𝑜𝑡𝑠𝐾𝑒𝑦𝐺𝑒𝑛𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑜𝑚𝑆𝑒𝑒𝑑sk_{i},pk_{i}\leftarrow wotsKeyGen(randomSeed)

So, every time the signing and verification with a specific key are only for that particular communication round. ∎

Final Miner Selection Using VRF.
Our role selection mechanism already selects miners mostly with the highest stake. Thus, we can simply select any miner to mine the final block. However, to make it fair, we use VRF to randomly select the miner. For that purpose, we compare our initial VRF output that we calculated in the beginning to select a role for the device with another VRF output that is calculated at the time of mining. The only difference is that this will be computed once for everyone. The miner with the initial VRF value closest to this new VRF output will be selected as the winning miner.

Proposition X.5.

Using VRF to select candidate blocks leverages the performance of BFL based on PoS preventing less forking.

Proof.

Suppose that we have m𝑚m the number of miners. Then, if we want to decide which miner’s block to be appended following Proof of Work, then the time t𝑡t required to achieve consensus is proportional to computational power (or hash power) c𝑐c, that is,

t∝cproportional-to𝑡𝑐t\propto c

To find the nonce in PoW,

t∝h​a​s​h​i​n​g​F​u​n​c​t​i​o​n​()​ . ​d​i​f​f​i​c​u​l​t​yproportional-to𝑡ℎ𝑎𝑠ℎ𝑖𝑛𝑔𝐹𝑢𝑛𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛 . 𝑑𝑖𝑓𝑓𝑖𝑐𝑢𝑙𝑡𝑦t\propto hashingFunction()\text{ . }difficulty

In Proof of Stake,

t∝c​o​i​n​A​g​eproportional-to𝑡𝑐𝑜𝑖𝑛𝐴𝑔𝑒t\propto coinAge

or

t∝r​a​n​d​o​m​F​u​n​c​t​i​o​n​S​p​e​e​d​()proportional-to𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑛𝑑𝑜𝑚𝐹𝑢𝑛𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛𝑆𝑝𝑒𝑒𝑑t\propto randomFunctionSpeed()

In our proposed method, we use VRF to select candidate blocks. Thus,

t∝V​R​F​f​u​n​c​t​i​o​n​S​p​e​e​d​()proportional-to𝑡𝑉𝑅𝐹𝑓𝑢𝑛𝑐𝑡𝑖𝑜𝑛𝑆𝑝𝑒𝑒𝑑t\propto VRFfunctionSpeed()

Here, VRFfunctionSpeed() is the only time it takes to select a candidate block. In traditional PoS, the time depends on many other factors, such as randomness, age of the coin, etc. For the forking event to occur, two or more miners blocks are appended by different groups of clients. Let us suppose n​M𝑛𝑀nM number of miners and n​D𝑛𝐷nD devices. The probability of a forking event occurring will be

P​(f​o​r​k​i​n​g)∝n​f​Mn​M​n​f​Dn​Dproportional-to𝑃𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑘𝑖𝑛𝑔𝑛𝑓𝑀𝑛𝑀𝑛𝑓𝐷𝑛𝐷P(forking)\propto\frac{nfM}{nM}\frac{nfD}{nD}

where, n​f​M𝑛𝑓𝑀nfM is the number of miners block appended by different devices and n​f​D𝑛𝑓𝐷nfD refers to the number of devices that appended different miners’ blocks causing forking. With the proposed selection of the candidate block VRF with the miners initially selected based on PoS, theoretically

P​(f​o​r​k​i​n​g)∼0similar-to𝑃𝑓𝑜𝑟𝑘𝑖𝑛𝑔0P(forking)\sim 0

since only the candidate block is propagated after the winner miner is selected to other nodes or devices. ∎

Proposition X.6.

The VRF PoS consensus is secure against the 51% attack and the 50% hash rate.

Proof.

In the proposed selection of the BFL role, there are two VRFs d​i​s​t​V​R​F​ and ​c​e​n​t​V​R​F𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑡𝑉𝑅𝐹 and 𝑐𝑒𝑛𝑡𝑉𝑅𝐹distVRF\text{ and }centVRF representing the distributed VRF that each device has and the central VRF that we use only once, respectively. In traditional PoS, a group that owns 51% staked cryptocurrency can alter the blockchain in their favor. In PoW, that is associated with 51% computational power. Thus, the probability of attack is

P​(a​t​t​a​c​k)∝51%​ (stake or computational power)proportional-to𝑃𝑎𝑡𝑡𝑎𝑐𝑘percent51 (stake or computational power)P(attack)\propto 51\%\text{ (stake or computational power)}

With the proposed approach,

P​(a​t​t​a​c​k)∝{P​(d​V​R​F​O​u​t∼c​V​R​F​O​u​t)}.(51%​a​t​t​a​c​k)formulae-sequenceproportional-to𝑃𝑎𝑡𝑡𝑎𝑐𝑘𝑃similar-to𝑑𝑉𝑅𝐹𝑂𝑢𝑡𝑐𝑉𝑅𝐹𝑂𝑢𝑡percent51𝑎𝑡𝑡𝑎𝑐𝑘P(attack)\propto\{P(dVRFOut\sim cVRFOut)\}.(51\%attack)

which is comparatively lower than without VRF. ∎

Proposition X.7.

Hyrbid Signature Scheme resolves the state issue of multilayer MSS.

In multilayer XMSS trees with d𝑑d layers, there are d−1𝑑1d-1 multiple signatures {σ1,σ2,..σd−1\sigma_{1},\sigma_{2},..\sigma_{d-1}} for each layer. These signatures are produced when upper-layer trees certify lower-layer XMSS trees. For a multilayer MSS with d𝑑d layers, the complexity of the multilayer MSS increases as d𝑑d increases. However, the proposed signature approach does not require d𝑑d layers of XMSS for more keys. Every time a new XMSS tree is created because we run out of keys in the previous XMSS tree. Therefore, the number of XMSS layers in the new proposed scheme is always equal to 111, which reduces the complexity of its implementation.

Proposition X.8.

The use of XMSS in the proposed hybrid approach is better than XMMS multitree or HSS schemes.

For a height XMSS scheme hℎh, the size of signature S​I​Gs​i​z​e𝑆𝐼subscript𝐺𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒SIG_{size} and the performance P𝑃P can be defined as,

S​I​Gs​i​z​e∝hproportional-to𝑆𝐼subscript𝐺𝑠𝑖𝑧𝑒ℎSIG_{size}\propto h

. In a hybrid approach, we use the height of the XMSS tree Hh<hsubscript𝐻ℎℎH_{h}<h.

Proposition X.9.

The proposed Hybrid Signature Approach solves the synchronization issues for XMSS that can occur if XMSS is used alone.

The proposed hybrid approach uses Dilithium to certify XMSS trees. Thus, the public key or hashed value of the Dilithium public key h​a​s​h​(p​kd)ℎ𝑎𝑠ℎ𝑝subscript𝑘𝑑hash(pk_{d}) can be used as the permanent address for the device. Thus, in this case, many XMSS trees can be generated and certified by Dilithium. Dilithium keys remain for the entire lifetime of the device.

Proposition X.10 (Correctness).

The correctness of the Hybrid Signature Scheme is formulated and proved here.

A digital signature uses a private key to sign a message which is verified later using a public key and signature. Both Dilithium and XMSS used in the hybrid scheme are postquantum digital signature algorithms recommended by NIST.

  1. 1.

    Keypair: Hybrid SS still uses XMSS predominantly for signing and verifying transactions. For verification, however, the XMSS tree is signed and verified by Dilithium. Thus,

    X​M​S​S​(s​i​g​n/v​e​r​i​f​y​(T​x))𝑋𝑀𝑆𝑆𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑖𝑓𝑦𝑇𝑥XMSS(sign/verify(Tx))

    whereas,

    D​i​l​i​t​h​i​u​m​(s​i​g​n/v​e​r​i​f​y​(X​M​S​S​t​r​e​e))𝐷𝑖𝑙𝑖𝑡ℎ𝑖𝑢𝑚𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑣𝑒𝑟𝑖𝑓𝑦𝑋𝑀𝑆𝑆𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑒Dilithium(sign/verify(XMSStree))
  2. 2.

    Hard to break: Both Dilithium and XMSS are post-quantum signature algorithms.

  3. 3.

    For signing Message, m∈M𝑚𝑀m\in M, the XMSS private key x​P​k𝑥𝑃𝑘xPk is used, whereas for verification, both d​S​i​gx𝑑𝑆𝑖subscript𝑔𝑥dSig_{x} and x​S​i​g𝑥𝑆𝑖𝑔xSig are verified.

Thus, the hybrid signature scheme is still a signature scheme that can be used to sign and verify transactions.

Proposition X.11.

Verification of only the Dilithium Signature of a particular XMSS tree is enough.

Initially, for a device, we have kt​hsuperscript𝑘𝑡ℎk^{th} XMSS tree (Xt​r​e​eksuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑒𝑘X_{tree}^{k}), it is public key (Xp​kksuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝑘𝑘X_{pk}^{k}), private key (Xs​kksuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑘𝑘X_{sk}^{k}) and Dilithium private key (Ds​ksubscript𝐷𝑠𝑘D_{sk}). Then, dilithium is used to sign Xp​kksuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝑘𝑘X_{pk}^{k} to generate Dilithium Signature as,

Ds​i​gk←Ds​i​g​n​(Ds​k,Xp​kk)←superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑘subscript𝐷𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑛subscript𝐷𝑠𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝑘𝑘D_{sig}^{k}\leftarrow D_{sign}(D_{sk},X_{pk}^{k})

For a transaction, t​x𝑡𝑥tx for a device disubscript𝑑𝑖d_{i} in a communication round r𝑟r, it is signed using XMSS tree Xt​r​e​eksuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑡𝑟𝑒𝑒𝑘X_{tree}^{k} , such that,

Xs​i​gk←Xs​i​g​n​(t​x,Xs​kk)←superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑘subscript𝑋𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑛𝑡𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑘𝑘X_{sig}^{k}\leftarrow X_{sign}(tx,X_{sk}^{k})

Xs​i​gsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑖𝑔X_{sig} contains the WOTS+ public key, authentication path and signed message.

In addition, the XMSS public key Xp​kksuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑝𝑘𝑘X_{pk}^{k} is derived from all public keys W​O​T​S+limit-from𝑊𝑂𝑇𝑆WOTS+. To verify XMSS, we compute the XMSS root from the authentication path. If the initial public key matches the newly computed root value of XMSS, then XMSS is verified i.e.

computedXMSSr​o​o​t==actualXMSSr​o​o​tcomputedXMSS_{root}==actualXMSS_{root}

With Hybrid Scheme, unless the Dilithium Signature is compromised, verifying the XMSS signature should be equivalent to verifying the signature of Dilithium Signature of that XMSS tree.

V​e​r​i​f​y​(ds​i​gk)∼V​e​r​i​f​y​(Xs​i​gk)similar-to𝑉𝑒𝑟𝑖𝑓𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑘𝑉𝑒𝑟𝑖𝑓𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑠𝑖𝑔𝑘Verify(d_{sig}^{k})\sim Verify(X_{sig}^{k})

Thus, verification of only the Dilithium Signature is enough.
